title: Ex-NFL CB Antonio Cromartie: Colts asked players not to kneel during national anthem
text:
USA TODAY

Former NFL cornerback Antonio Cromartie said the Indianapolis Colts pushed him in 2016 not to kneel in protest during the national anthem, alleging that his decision to do so anyway led to his release from the team and the end of his NFL career.

In a video for Bleacher Report, Cromartie said that then-Colts coach Chuck Pagano asked players in a locker-room speech before a Week 3 game at home against the San Diego Chargers not to follow in former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick's steps by kneeling during the anthem.

“I turned around to some of the guys and I spoke to them, and I’m like, ‘So when it’s about leukemia and your cancer, it’s cool. But when it’s about police brutality and social injustice, it’s not cool,’ ” Cromartie said. “I told Chuck Pagano that. I told him straight up, ‘Man, that’s (expletive).’ "

Pagano underwent treatments for a leukemia diagnosis in the middle of the 2012 season, which forced him to miss the second half of that season.

“It’s all ‘football is bigger than what is going on the outside,’ ” Cromartie continued. “No it ain’t. How about respecting the guys that’s getting murdered and killed by police officers? And I’m not saying all police officers is bad. But you get some, they get that little power in they hand and they abuse that power.”

During the fall owners meetings in 2016, Colts owner Jim Irsay said he didn’t think NFL games were the proper venue for players to express their personal views.

“It hasn't been a positive thing,” Irsay said of the protests. “What we all have to be aware of as players, owners, PR people, equipment managers, is when the lights go on we are entertainment. We are being paid to put on a show. There are other places to express yourself.”

Cromartie played 11 seasons in the league with the Chargers, Jets, Cardinals and Colts. He played in Indianapolis for less than one season. The team cut him after Week 4 of the 2016 season, when he was 32 years old.

“I can remember me, right before the national anthem, first time I took a knee,” Cromartie said. “What’s funny is, two or three of the executive guys were standing behind me and was like, ‘Cro, get up.’ I was like ‘Man, (expletive) y’all, I’m not getting up.’

“One person even had a towel to try to block it, you know for nobody wanting to take a picture, but they already had took a picture."

In several photographs taken from the Week 3 game, there are various personnel standing near Cromartie, but no one with a towel is visible in the images. Players and equipment managers appeared to be standing near Cromartie.

“And then Week 4, we are in London and they came up to me before the game and was like, ‘Hey, Cro, please don’t take a knee.’ So it was like, ‘Man, y’all better get out my face. Y’all not fitting to sit here and tell me what I can and cannot do.' I actually got benched that game. I got pulled out at halftime, and didn’t play the second half at all.”

While Cromartie did get benched, he also struggled in the game, allowing several big receptions to then-Jaguars receiver Allen Robinson, including a 3-yard touchdown in the first quarter in which Cromartie was turned around on a double move.

Cromartie also recounted how the Colts called him to release him two days after the London game. He said Pagano eventually told him that Indianapolis was cutting him because other defensive backs were getting healthy. Cromartie said he asked Pagano directly if his release had anything to do with his kneeling, and the cornerback said the coach reiterated that it was only because the team was getting healthier.

“I've said it before and I will say it again, every decision that we make as far as our roster goes and this team goes, is based on two things – what is best for this team and what gives us the best chance to win,” Pagano said after Cromartie was released.

Cromartie said he believed his decision kneel ended his career led to other teams not signing him.

“One hundred percent,” Cromartie said. “One hundred percent. It ain’t have nothing to do with my age. It ain’t have nothing to do with my style of play. It was because I took a knee. October 2nd was my last game. I got one workout that whole entire time, and that was by the Saints in 2017.”

Cromartie also said he got “death threats” over his kneeling, but said he didn’t regret his decision to protest social injustice.

“Why should I?” Cromartie said when asked if he regretted his decision to kneel. “ 'Cause at the end of the day, all we did was give people a voice that didn’t have a voice. And it brought more attention to what really was going on and now everybody’s talking about it. But there’s still no solution because it’s still going on.”

Follow Lorenzo Reyes on Twitter @LorenzoGReyes.
description: Former NFL cornerback Antonio Cromartie said that ex-Colts coach Chuck Pagano told his team not to kneel during the national anthem.
